page.title: 04BLACKHILL QUARRY
page.content: Over 300 million years ago, a swift-running stream, 3 miles wide, flowed from Gloucestershire to France by way of Somerset and Devon. It laid down a gravel bed and it is on this Bunter sandstone that Blackhill Quarry is sited. The sand and pebbles are products of the friction caused by that stream. There have been diggings here since 1900's, when there was also a militia camp on the site. The present quarry has a 'life' of 26 yrs (2011). 5 million gallons of water are stored at the quarry and 800,000 galls are used daily for washing the sand from the gravel economically. The water is recirculated through the plant from the Silt Ponds. It is also used for fire fighting on Woodbury Common.As each area is exhausted, reclaimation is carried out.
